newsitem.title: EGYPT: Egypt earns record $3 billion a year from tourism.
newsitem.headline: Egypt earns record $3 billion a year from tourism.

text.p: Egypt earned a record of more than $3 billion from tourism in the 1995-96 fiscal year, up 30.9 percent from the previous year, the government newspaper al-Gomhuria said on Sunday.

Tourism Minister Mamdouh el-Beltagi said in Alexandria that foreign exchange receipts from tourism amounted to just over $3 billion during the year, $710 million more than in 1994-95. The year ends on June 30.
According to figures released by the tourism ministry earlier, the number of people visiting Egypt in 1995-96 was 3.620 million, 27.8 percent more than in 1994-95.
Tourism in the 1995 calendar year had already matched the record-breaking year 1992. Attacks on tourist targets by Islamist militants had led to a slump in 1993 and 1994.

The last attack was in March this year, when gunmen massacred 18 Greek tourists outside a Cairo hotel. But it appeared to be an isolated incident and its effect on tourist arrivals was both minor and short-lived.
Tourism is Egypt's third largest source of foreign exchange, after remittances from Egyptians abroad and visible exports.
